poem:
Sidecar Grammar

In Brasília's clean blue sentence  
three dogs arrange themselves by habit—  
goggles, grin, sweetness up front—  
as the man tilts the bike  
so the sidecar briefly forgets the earth.

A phone on a tripod watches,  
patient as a parked thought,  
while wind conjugates their joy  
across their faces:  
I ride, you fly, we are.
